The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory, which has been successfully applied to other foundational problems in mathematics. However, the mathematical structure of quantum theory is so far-reaching that it is not clear how to formulate the axioms of quantum theory in this language. In this paper, we show that the axioms of quantum theory can be formulated purely categorically, without presupposing any analytical structure. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is both general and precise.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a minimal level, with a small genome and a lack of key signaling pathways and transcriptional factors important for multicellular development. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This process may have been a prerequisite for the evolution of parasitism. (Less)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis and has led to a high mortality rate. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host innate immune response by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, which are key factors for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Here, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this evasion mechanism. We demonstrate that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1. This interaction is required for the ability of Orf6 to block nuclear import of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and to impair the IFN antagonistic function of Orf6. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host antiviral response and could lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 60% to meet this demand. This increase in demand will be accompanied by a rise in global temperatures, which will increase the frequency of extreme weather events. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize yields and yields variability in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. It shows that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 86% under 4 °C of global warming. This study also shows that the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases to values much larger than present-day values, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% increases from 0% to 70% under 4 °C of global warming. These results highlight the need for urgent investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of LMH in African savanna ecosystems. They also provide a proof-of-concept for the use of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition in herbivore feces. This approach could be applied to other ecosystems and taxa to better understand the role of herbivores in shaping biodiversity. (Less)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only about 2 wk of cash on hand. Many businesses anticipate accessing the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems accessing the program. We also assess the impact of loans relative to grants.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean has become a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude and the fate of this pollution are still open questions. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris by nano-fragmentation and transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes. This study provides a global view of the fate of plastic debris in the ocean and highlights the importance of size-selective sinks in the open ocean. It also provides a framework for the design of future experiments to resolve the fate of the missing plastic debris. This framework is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. VX-765 also protected substantia nigra neurons from degeneration. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the management of this orphan disease. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controls blood pressure, and regulates inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, allowing for rapid and robust communication between cells. This study reveals the nature of the communication network and its design principles. The findings provide insight into the design of the communication network and its role in the control of the endothelium. The findings also provide insight into the design of communication networks in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at https://covidcast.org.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. It also provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the selectivity filter and the inactivation gate in other ion-channel families. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for natural products to regulate the composition of the microbiome is an emerging field of research. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the membership of the gut microbiome. We identify a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi and provide evidence that these fungi are actively producing these compounds in the gut. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This work provides a foundation for the discovery of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This could lead to the development of new therapeutics and the prevention of disease. (Less Less)

Anxiety is a major risk factor for social disorders, yet the mechanisms underlying social competitiveness remain elusive. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We identify a crucial role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in social behavior. We also show that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is critical for social hierarchy establishment and that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, can prevent the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic explanation for the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. These findings have important implications for understanding the pathophysiology of social disorders and for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability to design mechanical devices with desired behaviors is essential for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple hyperelastic materials that seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit complex and organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. The physically realized responses are highly complex and navigable, which are unachievable by a single material. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to design other complex systems, such as soft robots and soft materials. This work provides a general framework for the design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene family is composed of four globin genes, alpha (α), beta (β), delta (δ), and gamma (γ), which are expressed in different tissues and under different conditions. The hemoglobin genes are transcribed into multiple mRNA species, which are translated into different hemoglobin polypeptides. The hemoglobin genes are also subject to developmental regulation, with fetal hemoglobin levels rising during fetal development and declining in adults. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) mediates developmental regulation of fetal hemoglobin levels in humans. IGF2BP1 is expressed in erythroid cells and mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This knowledge may be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies. It may also be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies.

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease and a major risk factor for heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with heart failure, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for treating hypertension. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal land in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition, but that declines of older-forest–associated bird populations accelerated. This is partly because of fires on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP’s goal of reversing the decline of older forests has not been achieved, and the creation of early-seral ecosystems may impede the development of older-forest structure. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will require continued monitoring and adaptive management.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for global health. We present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics by screening acylide antibiotics based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train the network on large datasets. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and other countries. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime suppresses melatonin and phase-delays the circadian clock, which may have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, the disease was not fatal. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but not for its maintenance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification and traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We propose that the acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that enable efficient digestion of plant cell walls, including lignocellulose, triggered the Mesozoic diversification of specialized herbivorous beetles. This resulted in the nearly half of all living beetles being specialized herbivores. Thus, the evolution of beetles appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable efficient digestion of plant cell walls. This study provides insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. (Less Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation SARS-CoV-2 vaccines and therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We manipulated population size such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results indicate that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the emergence of culture.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. APOE is also known to be highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly involved in synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we show that APOE isoform is also highly associated with the rate of astrocytic synapse pruning. We also show that APOE4 is associated with increased accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to AD pathology. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and suggest that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help explain the increased AD risk associated with APOE4. These studies also provide a rationale for the use of APOE2 as a therapeutic target in AD. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is the densest part of the Earth, and it is the only part of the Earth that is not in hydrostatic equilibrium. The inner core is a unique part of the Earth that has been studied for more than 100 y. However, the inner core is still a mysterious part of the Earth. The inner core is believed to have formed by crystallization of the liquid core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. This study provides a new insight into the inner core formation by showing that the inner core is likely formed by two steps: first, nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron, and second, nucleation of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This study also provides a clue to understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core.

Marijuana legalization is a major public health issue, and the need to understand the neurobiological mechanisms of its effects is urgent. Here, we show that marijuana abusers show reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]), which is consistent with their increased irritability, anxiety, and addiction. These findings suggest that the brain DA responses to methylphenidate might be a useful biomarker for predicting the effects of chronic marijuana use.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and understanding its neural basis is a major goal of cognitive neuroscience. We show that the most powerful artificial neural network models for predicting the next word in a sentence also predict brain responses to those sentences in humans. This suggests that the brain’s processing of language is shaped by the predictive power of the sentence-level input. This is the first computationally explicit demonstration that predictive processing shapes the brain’s representation of language. These results have implications for theories of language processing and for the design of artificial intelligence. They also provide a promising approach for studying other higher-level cognitive functions.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is not intrinsic to DL but rather a consequence of the difficulty of the optimization problem. We prove that there are problems where no algorithm can find a stable solution, even if it is universal. This result is a step toward understanding the limits of machine learning. It also has implications for scientific computing, where there are problems that can be solved only by unstable algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including people’s inability to understand exponential growth. This claim is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. The experiment’s critical design flaws were overlooked at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of how people misunderstand exponential growth. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a Mexican patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of M. leprae. The genomes are similar in size and synteny, and protein-coding genes share 93% nucleotide sequence identity. However, 50% of the genes in M. lepromatosis are pseudogenes, and the two species have accumulated new pseudogenes or specific deletions since their divergence. M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA than M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides insights into the evolution of the leprosy pathogen and its impact on the evolution of the human genome. (PsycINFO Database Record

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classical statistical mechanics. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nontrivial problem, which has resisted a complete solution so far. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit for the study of quantum quenches. We provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain, which is integrable at all times. Our results pave the way for a systematic study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. To combat the pandemic, a vaccine is needed that is safe, effective, and easily accessible. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. This vaccine strain is highly attenuated in vivo, resulting in reduced lung pathology and weight loss. In addition, the vaccine strain generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies and a robust immune response against the spike protein. Importantly, the vaccine strain is temperature sensitive in vivo, resulting in reduced viral loads and protection against lethal challenge with wild-type virus. These properties make the vaccine strain a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine is currently in clinical development. Thus, we anticipate that it will be available for use in the near future. This will help in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. (Less)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the Black Death is still debated, but it is generally assumed that plague was spread by rats. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors of plague during this period. This finding challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats, and it has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague and its control.

The HSP90 chaperone family is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including protein folding and the regulation of metabolic pathways. The TRAP1 member of this family is found predominantly in mitochondria, where it is involved in the regulation of apoptosis. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is known to sever filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to monitor and quantify the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments and induces severing in a mechanical torque-dependent manner. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF’s ability to sever actin filaments is enhanced in the context of cell biology. They also provide a general framework for understanding how mechanical forces can enhance the activity of other molecular motors and enzymes. This framework may be useful in understanding other biological processes. Finally, our results have implications for understanding the role of ADF in various diseases. For example, mutations in ADF have been linked to cancer and other diseases. Our results suggest that these mutations may affect ADF’s ability to induce severing. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food, which may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that fructose may be a stronger stimulant of reward processing than glucose, which may increase the risk of overconsumption of high-calorie foods. The findings have implications for understanding the impact of the food environment on eating behavior and for the development of strategies to reduce overconsumption of high-calorie foods. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They also provide a framework for the study of the genomic diversity of the Indian Ocean islands

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, as well as for our understanding of the mechanisms of emotional contagion.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only RNAs that are translated. Messenger RNA modifications can also affect protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the most common mRNA modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that mRNA modifications can have subtle effects on translation that can be important for cellular processes. Our work provides insight into how mRNA modifications can affect protein synthesis and may help to explain how mRNA modifications can influence protein function. (Less Less)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to a range of sensitivity analyses and are not explained by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study provides evidence for the importance of a sense of worthwhile living in older age.

The common cold is the most common viral infection worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold in the United States. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of the common cold. They also provide insights into the evolution of temperature-dependent growth in the common cold virus. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus and may help to design therapeutic strategies for the treatment of the common cold. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces. This mechanosensory system is essential for the pathogen to attach to surfaces and to induce virulence and biofilm formation. The mechanosensitive pili-mediated surface sensing system is a chemotaxis-like pathway that regulates the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. This system is important for the pathogen to adapt to its environment and to induce virulence and biofilm formation. The presence of pesticides in surface waters is a global concern. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies (>2,500 sites in 73 countries) that evaluates the presence of particularly toxic agricultural insecticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. These efforts are urgently needed to protect the global aquatic environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on society, and the SARS-CoV-2 virus has spread to many animal species, including deer. We found that SARS-CoV-2 RNA was detected in 33% of deer samples collected over a 12-mo period. The majority of deer-to-deer transmissions occurred during the peak of the deer hunting season, suggesting that deer are a significant source of SARS-CoV-2 transmission to humans. Our findings highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach will be critical to understanding the potential for future viral spillover events and the development of effective mitigation strategies. Our study also highlights the importance of deer as a reservoir for SARS-CoV-2, and the need to study the ecology of this virus in free-living animals. This will help to inform the development of effective strategies to mitigate the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in the wild. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, biodiversity, and people’s livelihoods. This paper examines the causes of this problem and proposes solutions. The main causes are the lack of information about the environmental and social impacts of dams, the lack of transparency in the decision-making process, and the lack of accountability for the consequences of building dams. The paper also examines the importance of incorporating climate change into the decision-making process. The paper concludes with a proposal for a new approach to hydropower that can move toward sustainability.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ deposits and cell death. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of producing potent inflammatory factors, and that these are released into the extracellular environment in the presence of increasing levels of soluble and oligomeric Aβ. We demonstrate that these neuron-derived cytokines correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. Thus, we identify the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The present study provides evidence for the earliest known evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the Southern Levant, which is dated to the Hellenistic period (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.). The results are based on a detailed faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and a survey of the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. The results suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study contributes to a better understanding of the role of chickens in the development of the agricultural economy in the ancient Mediterranean world. (Less Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood in detail. The folding of a single protein is a challenging problem, but it is even more difficult to understand the folding of a large protein, such as a virus capsid protein. Here we show that the folding of a large protein can be studied in detail by following the folding of a single protein in time. We show that the folding of maltose binding protein can be studied in detail by following the folding of a single protein in time. We show that the folding of a large protein can be studied in detail by following the folding of a single protein in time. This approach can be extended to study the folding of large protein complexes.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that arginine supplementation is not effective in restoring immune function after sepsis. On the contrary, arginine supplementation increases the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells, which are associated with poor clinical outcome. In contrast, citrulline supplementation is more efficient in restoring immune function and decreasing the risk of late mortality. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to reduce sepsis-induced immunosuppression and improve clinical outcome. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system, when perturbed, returns to its original state at a rate proportional to its current activity. SOC is observed in nature and in many physical systems. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models and the implications of our discovery for the study of SOC.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of fungicides. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and the molecular mechanisms of action are not well understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of a unique antifungal peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate that this peptide binds to bioactive phosphoinositides and penetrates fungal cell walls, followed by accumulation in the cytoplasm and nucleoli. These results provide insights into the structural basis of antifungal activity and the mode of action of this peptide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction that is likely to be important for the success of reproductive interactions. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of Drosophila sperm and show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the viability of sperm during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular mechanisms that underlie the male–female reproductive interface. (PsycINFO Database Record

Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The results also suggest that the mechanism of action of other proteins that bind to platelets, such as antithrombin, is similar. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and provides a resource for researchers to study the impact of viruses on human health. Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the early Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. They are also involved in diseases such as arrhythmia and heart failure. Ion channels are composed of protein subunits that form pores in the lipid bilayer. The pore gates are the protein subunits that open and close the pore. Ion channels normally have two types of pore gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels have a slow C-type inactivation gate that is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. This finding provides a new insight into the mechanism of slow inactivation and may help to understand the pathogenesis of arrhythmia and heart failure. It also provides a potential target for the development of drugs to treat arrhythmia and heart failure. (PsycINFO Database Record

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis process. The parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) is required for parasite invasion in most parasite strains, but its function is unknown. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the red cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. We isolate the changes in the cytoskeleton and membrane and show that reduction in the bending modulus is directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These data suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the malaria parasite invasion process. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a bottom-up parser that merges words into phrases, and it provides initial evidence for the reality of this parser in the brain. Our results suggest that the brain compresses sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is a fundamental property of language that may be important for understanding the brain’s efficient processing of the language stream.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates many aspects of development. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of redundant genes and their regulation in development. It also provides a model for the regulation of redundant genes in other biological systems. This work may also be of interest to biologists interested in the regulation of gene expression.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the substantia nigra pars reticulata and locus coeruleus. This circuit may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen is a key trait for plants. However, the ability to fix nitrogen is limited to a few plant species, and the symbiosis with nitrogen-fixing bacteria is a complex and poorly understood process. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley plants, using a bacterial signal that is produced by the plant. This method represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria are only able to fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. It also provides a proof of principle for the use of bacterial signals as a means to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in the fields of symbiosis, nitrogen fixation, and synthetic biology.

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the high degree of uncertainty around the estimates. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be applied in other tropical forest landscapes.

Animals use their bodies to sense the environment, but the body size of animals is limited by the laws of physics. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can sense sound without a body by outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider can increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study provides insights into the evolution of sensing and the design of acoustic devices. It also provides a unique model system for studying the evolution of extended and regenerative sensing. This study is of interest to biologists, physicists, engineers, and chemists.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are often considered separately. We show that the health benefits of reducing air pollution are much larger than previously thought, and that they can be further increased by reducing the emissions of other anthropogenic sources. This is because air pollution and aerosols have opposite effects on the climate system, and thus, reducing air pollution can cool the climate system and increase rainfall, while reducing greenhouse gases and aerosols can warm the climate system and decrease rainfall. Our results suggest that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) lack access to vaccines. We report a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that is suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing, which could yield billions of doses annually. This vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that mediates viral entry to cells. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, a high-yield manufacturability profile, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. The engineered protein can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered protein and VLP can be produced in a wide range of microbial hosts, which could enable global access to vaccines. This engineered protein and VLP could be used to develop a global vaccine strategy that includes LMICs.

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer of neural crest-derived tissues. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALKALs activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. We further show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for zebrafish iridophore patterning in vivo. These results provide evidence that ALKALs are ligands for ALK/LTK family receptors and that these receptors are involved in neural crest development. Our results also provide evidence that zebrafish ALKALs are secreted proteins that are processed into smaller bioactive forms. These findings are important for understanding the role of ALKALs in human neuroblastoma and for the development of small molecule inhibitors of ALKALs. They also provide insights into the mechanisms of neural crest patterning in the zebrafish embryo and in the eye of Drosophila melanogaster. Finally, our findings suggest that zebrafish ALKALs are processed into bioactive forms that are secreted and that this processing is important for their biological activity. The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its emergence. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a better understanding of the origins of plague and its evolution, which is essential for the development of effective countermeasures. (Less Less)

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the future of agriculture and the global climate. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance and diversify crop rotations can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated SOC in the United States Midwest. These practices also increase the activity of soil microbes, which can be a key driver of SOC storage. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and highlight the importance of soil health management practices in agricultural systems worldwide. These results also highlight the importance of rotational grazing in the management of grasslands and the potential of this practice to increase soil C storage. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing the threat of emerging viruses. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans and used this to systematically rank the spillover potential of 887 viruses from 74,635 animals. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a blueprint for the systematic identification of viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. We show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergent evolution of this trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon. This work provides evidence that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for the production of this pigment. (Less Less)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The receptor and cellular entry machinery of a pathogen are critical determinants of its pathogenicity. Here, we report that two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, can use human dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) as their receptor and human cellular proteases as their entry machinery. In contrast, MERS coronavirus, which currently causes outbreaks in humans, can use DPP4 and human cellular proteases for efficient human cell entry. These findings suggest that the receptor and entry machinery of bat coronaviruses are important determinants of their ability to cause cross-species transmission. They also suggest that the emergence of bat coronaviruses that can use human cells for cross-species transmission is a major threat to human health. Our study provides insights into the molecular basis of the emergence of MERS coronavirus and other bat coronaviruses that can cause cross-species transmission. It also provides a basis for the development of vaccines and antivirals against these emerging threats to human health. (PsycINFO Database Record

The human genome is replicated by two DNA polymerases, pol δ and pol ε. The lagging strand of the DNA double helix is replicated by pol δ, which is responsible for synthesizing the Okazaki fragments. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme has not been characterized. Here, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of lagging strand DNA synthesis. It also provides a foundation for the development of therapeutic strategies to treat cancer. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of DNA replication.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it has been possible to synthesize simple RNA molecules, but the ability to synthesize functional RNA molecules from scratch has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the successful in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This work demonstrates that the building blocks of life can be assembled in the laboratory from scratch using RNA.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in neighborhoods that are physically attractive to residents and outsiders alike. These results have implications for urban planning and policy.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. We have identified that the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. We demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide that is secreted and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the control of fungal interactions with other microbes. It also provides a model for the discovery of new antifungal agents. (PsycINFO Database Record

The impact of late-spring frosts on plant performance is poorly understood, despite their ecological and economic impact on agriculture and forestry. We use a global dataset of frost events to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. We find that trees in regions where late-spring frosts are common are cautious (late-leafing) in their leaf-out strategies, whereas trees in regions where they are rare are opportunistic. Given species’ innate resistance strategies, we estimate that ∼35% of the European and ∼26% of the Asian temperate forest area, but only ∼10% of the North American, will experience increasing late-frost damage in the future. Our findings inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. They also highlight the importance of studying the evolutionary impacts of climate change. Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether Th17 cells are required for disease or merely contribute to it. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to disease by inducing the development of Th1-like cells. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of Th1 cells, suggesting that Th17 cells are potent mediators of disease. These results have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins and by superoxide dismutase (SOD1) and C9orf72 expansion. We report a method to rapidly convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. These cells are toxic to motor neurons, suggesting a common mechanism in ALS. This method now enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the ability of the pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum to colonize the vector. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of A. phagocytophilum to colonize the vector. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the arthropod vector to enhance transmission of infectious diseases. It also provides a model for how pathogens may use host-derived molecules to manipulate the microbiota of their vector. This work may also have implications for the development of vector control strategies. (Less Less)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. The discovery of a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This finding is important for understanding the causes of past climate change and for predicting future climate change. It also has implications for the design of climate mitigation strategies.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color in response to environmental cues. This ability is known as chromatophoresis. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green chromatophoresis has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution. We also describe a new mechanism for chromatophoresis, which relies on a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in the blood. This discovery provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green chromatophoresis and introduces a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. Our results also provide a molecular explanation for the evolution of green coloration in anurans, which is a widespread group of amphibians that is able to change its color in response to environmental cues. Finally, our results provide a molecular explanation for the evolution of blue-green coloration in the fossil record. (Less Less)

The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is a key feature of cancer progression and metastasis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α pathways. ALKBH5 overexpression increases NANOG levels and the percentage of BCSCs, whereas knockdown of ALKBH5 decreases the percentage of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in hypoxic tumors may contribute to the maintenance of BCSCs and the progression of breast cancer. This study provides insight into the role of m6A modification in the maintenance of the BCSC phenotype. This information may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer.
