The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and multifactorial, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most prevalent mutation in the virus currently circulating in the population. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent membrane fusion.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y, both of which are the largest declines since 2000. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our projections highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to and mortality from COVID-19 and other infectious diseases.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are of fundamental importance in many fields of science. In this work, we propose a new way to measure the chemical properties of atoms, which is based on the chemical potential of the electron. We show that this new measure is a good predictor of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. This work provides a new perspective on the chemical properties of atoms and opens the door to the study of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions and show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results suggest that ignitions and fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of active and passive fire suppression in driving future fire regimes and the need to better understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon in Earth system models. This is critical for understanding the potential for climate change mitigation through fire management.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is synchronized with the host’s circadian clock. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-mediated control of symbiont numbers may be a general strategy used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for how the host’s glycan production may be used to regulate the activities of the symbionts in a mutualism. This work also provides a new example of how the host’s circadian clock may be used to regulate the activities of its symbionts. (Less Less)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a large corpus of violent death narratives from the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We find that the corpus contains many topics that are not captured by existing structured variables. We also find that the corpus contains a gender bias in the topics it identifies. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify biases in the data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia and arrived in Europe in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease was caused by Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that is transmitted by fleas. The introduction of Y. pestis into Europe is generally understood as the result of a single introduction of the bacterium into a European harbor, after which the disease spread throughout Europe. We show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate fluctuations that preceded plague outbreaks in Europe. Instead, we find that plague outbreaks were preceded by reintroductions of Y. pestis into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. This suggests that the introduction of Y. pestis into Europe was the result of multiple introductions, which were delayed by 15 y. Our results suggest that the introduction of Y. pestis into Europe was not the result of a single event, but rather of multiple introductions, which were delayed by 15 y. This finding has implications for our understanding of the spread of plague in Europe.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases affecting marine ecosystems worldwide. The disease is caused by a densovirus that has spread rapidly across the Pacific Ocean, affecting at least 20 species of asteroids. The present study provides evidence that the densovirus is the causative agent of the disease. The virus was detected in plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that the virus is spread by the food web. The findings provide a strong basis for developing control strategies to mitigate the spread of the disease. The results also highlight the importance of studying the history of disease agents in museum specimens. This is because the presence of the densovirus in museum specimens of asteroids from 1942 suggests that the disease has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. This is the first report of a densovirus affecting asteroids. The findings are of global significance because asteroids are a major component of the marine ecosystem and are widely distributed in the world’s oceans. The findings also have implications for other marine organisms that are susceptible to densoviruses. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge in AML research, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibody-based therapies targeting IL1RAP in AML

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation SARS-CoV-2 vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their assessments are key to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert network can be used to provide a more accurate and timely assessment of crop conditions, and can be used to complement official forecasts. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this, but the neural basis of memory is still poorly understood. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is able to store information over short and long time periods, and is sensitive to context and serial order. It is not dependent on synaptic plasticity or inhibitory feedback, and is therefore a candidate for the neural basis of memory in the brain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This information is critical for predicting the future trajectory of the global carbon cycle and the potential for further climate change.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, because the molecular consequences of this change are not fully understood. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This model can be used to predict the molecular signature of the transition to parasitism in the genomes of extant parasitic organisms. This signature can be used to infer the evolutionary history of the transition to parasitism in the genomes of extinct organisms. Finally, this model can be used to predict the molecular signature of the transition to parasitism in the genomes of extant parasitic organisms. This signature can be used to infer the evolutionary history of the transition to parasitism in the genomes of extinct organisms.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water security. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional downscaling of climate models for risk assessment. This approach can be applied to other regions and countries. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed in the seconds after the explosion, provides a unique window into the conditions under which quasicrystals are formed. This discovery also demonstrates that the conditions for the formation of quasicrystals are more widespread than previously thought.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the pathway, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (PsycINFO Database Record

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 is known to be involved in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes ameliorated EAE severity, whereas ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades because of the influence of global warming on the probability of warm and dry conditions. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created acute human and ecosystem impacts. This finding has important implications for water management, agriculture, and wildfire risk in California and other regions that are experiencing or are likely to experience similar changes in climate. Our results also highlight the importance of anthropogenic climate change in understanding the causes of extreme events and the need for mitigation and adaptation strategies to reduce the risks associated with climate change.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis. The genetic etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present across cultures and continents. However, individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is also evident, and this work highlights the potential for more positive content to be more widely shared. These findings help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 are associated with immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that result in hematological abnormalities and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a rationale for the use of the CRAC channel as a therapeutic target in the treatment of immune dysfunction and myopathy. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of lysosomes with the cell membrane. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases (i.e., plasmin, trypsin, and elastase) to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. In mammals, there are two SHMT isozymes, one in the cytosol and one in the mitochondria. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth in vivo. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cancer cells and in a cell-line screen. Finally, we show that cancer cells with defective glycine import are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. These findings have implications for cancer therapy and for the design of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. (Less)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons and is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins. These proteins are highly aggregation-prone and form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions contain proteins that are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners. This suggests that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the formation of inclusions in ALS and suggest that the inclusion bodies are a result of a metastable state of the proteins. This metastable state is likely a consequence of the disease-related progressive loss of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. Our results also suggest that the metastable state of the proteins may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases. This may be relevant to the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The earliest angiosperms are poorly understood, and the origin of the group is still a matter of debate. The study presented here focuses on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. Based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, the morphology and anatomy of Montsechia suggest that it is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group that is sister to eudicots. This raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Archaefructus and Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides evidence that humans have been infected by B19V for a long time, which is important for understanding the history of the disease. Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. We use satellite altimeter data to estimate the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y and find that it is accelerating. This acceleration is consistent with the rate of acceleration of global mean temperature rise over the same period. We also find that the rate of sea level rise is increasing, which is consistent with the findings of the IPCC AR5.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal in enzymology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into both structure and chemical dynamics, including the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, but an isostere benzimidazole does not. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. It also highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates in other enzymes. (Less)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is currently in clinical use for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit to patients, healthcare workers, and the wider community.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning rhythm is established only in the mature symbiosis, suggesting that it is a critical factor in the establishment of a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how animals can regulate the activities of their symbionts. It also suggests that other animals may use this same strategy to regulate the activities of their symbionts. This may be important for understanding the evolution of symbiosis and the maintenance of health in animal–microbe associations. (Less Less)

Suspension rates in US schools are high and rising. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this mindset can be sustained. Moreover, this mindset can be taught to students, and it can be sustained over time. Finally, this intervention can be scaled up to reduce suspension rates. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how MERS-CoV infects human cells, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions, and it is therefore important to understand how to encourage people to make more sustainable dietary choices. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 60% or more. This is a simple and scalable intervention that could be implemented in many settings. It is therefore a promising approach for encouraging more sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. This interface is dramatically remodeled in cancer cells, and the surfaceome is a potential target for cancer therapy. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to study the surfaceome of a panel of breast epithelial cells expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with glycoproteomics, and find massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for studying the surfaceome in cancer cells. It also provides a resource for the cancer research community to study the surfaceome of their own cancer cell lines. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout and vote share. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostics and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and may be important for immune evasion and/or evasion of the antiviral response. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and protein kinase Cε (PKCε). This leads to an up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression, which contributes to the development of cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be developed as a therapeutic strategy for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study also provides a rationale for the use of CRF antagonists in the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycINFO Database Record

The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we address the problem of “selective inference.” This is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations that we find in data. The fact that we have “cherry picked”—searched for the strongest associations—means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is a challenge that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vascular networks in vivo. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTK biology. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands display a severe impairment in iridophore patterning, which is mediated by the Alk/Ltk/augmentor signaling pathway. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the physiological role of augmentor ligands and their link to Ltk signaling. It also provides a model system to study the function of augmentor ligands in a vertebrate model. This study may also have implications for the development of Alk/Ltk inhibitors as cancer therapeutics.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global STING knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING−/− beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process for the production of infectious virions. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. They also suggest that the lack of conservation of this interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This might have implications for the emergence of new influenza A viruses. (Less)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the formation of atheroprone phenotypes in endothelial cells (ECs). The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that YAP/TAZ is activated by disturbed flow and plays a critical role in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development and identifies YAP/TAZ as a therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that were extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies and examine the geographic and seasonal extent of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. We find that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then connect these changes to economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement, (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience improvement, and (iii) neighborhoods that are physically proximate to attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in neighborhoods that are physically attractive to residents and outsiders alike. These results have implications for urban planning and policy.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study also provides a model system for studying the evolution of chemosensory receptors in arthropods. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response in the pathogenesis of ZIKV is still unclear. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the eclipse phase for ZIKV is most likely short. We also estimate the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. Finally, we assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. This work provides a framework for the design of future clinical trials and for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Less Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood, and the consequences of bleaching on coral reefs are expected to become more severe in the future due to climate change. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling is a key factor in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, and that this process is a major driver of the functional breakdown of the coral holobiont. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates nutrient absorption and immune responses. In the absence of tumor growth, the epithelium is maintained in a healthy state by a delicate balance between immune surveillance and microbial colonization. However, in the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a loss of host–microbe homeostasis. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, which triggers a regenerative response and promotes tumor growth. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of JNK in cancer and cancer therapy. Our study provides a framework for understanding the crosstalk between tumors and the microbiome in cancer and cancer therapy. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to chemotherapy is a major problem. In this study, we found that the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 was expressed in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). ROR1 expression also enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This study also provides a rationale for the use of the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab in combination with chemotherapy in the treatment of breast cancer. The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is difficult to reconcile with the timing of the climate changes. We show that a series of massive volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a strong climate response, including a shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. This is a unique and unexpected link between volcanism and climate that may help to explain the timing of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, providing food, livelihoods, and recreation to hundreds of millions of people. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of ecosystem services. We derive a gridded map of global riverine fisheries and use it to assess the implications of fishing for biodiversity conservation, fishery sustainability, and food security. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. The spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are responsible for the high capacity and the low operating potential range. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the nervous system. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate is not a property of a single pathway but rather a property of the entire nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of DNA replication. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and is also involved in the repair of DNA damage. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that of a mouse strain with a mutation in a gene that regulates recombination. We find that the distribution of recombination in Mimulus is similar to that in yeast, suggesting that the process of recombination in flowering plants may be similar to that in the earliest eukaryotic cells.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The identification of resting state networks (RSNs) is a key step in understanding the functional organization of the brain. Here, we used metabolic PET to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We observed that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. They also suggest that the RSN organization may be a useful biomarker for the early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally, and that only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This finding suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of NAD-RNA in eukaryotes raises the possibility that it could be involved in the regulation of gene expression.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We examined whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) persist at certain loci associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results provide evidence for a role of epigenetic mechanisms in the maintenance of metabolic memory. They also suggest that epigenetic mechanisms may be targeted to improve the long-term control of diabetes and its complications. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective targeted therapies. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The mechanisms underlying the development of this disorder are not fully understood. In this study, we found that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides evidence that gut dysfunction is a potential mechanism of relapse in alcohol dependence. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato fruit flavor is unknown. Here, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of 2-substituted tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid substrates into the corresponding 2-substituted oxime, nitro, and nitrile volatiles. This pathway is unique to tomato fruit and is a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving the flavor of this important crop. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of this gene family as a target for the production of other nitrogenous volatiles in plants. (Less)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in isolation. Here we show that changes in temperature can alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and that this relationship is not constant but rather depends on the temperature at which biodiversity is measured. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of taxa, and highlights the importance of species interactions in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for spatial memory. It is thought to encode a map of local space, but how this is organized is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from large numbers of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode local space, are strongly clustered, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells tend to intermingle. These results suggest that grid cells are not completely isolated from other cell types, but that they are strongly coupled among themselves. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its subregions and may help to elucidate the mechanisms of spatial memory. It also provides a platform for future studies of the neural basis of navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. Understanding the mechanisms of flowering regulation in host–parasite interactions may help to understand the evolution of flowering in plants. This study also illustrates the importance of photoperiod as an environmental cue in flowering regulation.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides insight into the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system and its potential role in health and disease. The striosome–dendron bouquets are likely to be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This may be why we click with some people and not others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, called SAN cells (SANCs), which are responsible for heart rate control. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia that is associated with an increased risk of stroke. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, is selectively expressed in SANCs. We show that STIM1 regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs by influencing the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry, L-type Ca2+ current, and Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These findings reveal a previously unrecognized role for STIM1 in SANC Ca2+ signaling and contribute to our understanding of SAN dysfunction in atrial fibrillation. This study also provides a rationale for targeting STIM1 as a therapeutic strategy for treating atrial fibrillation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of jasmonate (JA)-mediated defense responses. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice from insect attack. This study also provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the interaction between Si and JA in plant defense. (PsycINFO Database Record

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages in response to IFN-γ and lipopolysaccharide. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for our understanding of macrophage biology and for the development of new therapeutic strategies for inflammatory diseases. This article is protected by copyright. Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this, but the neurobiological substrate of memory remains unclear. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a neurobiological account of memory that is based on the dynamic properties of neurons. It provides a mechanism for the binding of linguistic features over time, which is a key feature of language. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can deliver biomolecules across the lipid bilayer of mammalian cells and that this strategy can be extended to plants. We demonstrate that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a roadmap for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work also provides a roadmap for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is a major driver of coastal eutrophication in large lakes, but it has been overlooked in most regulatory and monitoring efforts. We show that small tributaries can deliver large amounts of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large lakes, where they can fuel algal blooms. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on these sources to protect valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our results also highlight the need to better understand the role of dams in altering nutrient loading from small tributaries. Although dams are a common feature of many large watersheds, they are often overlooked in nutrient loading assessments. Our findings suggest that dams may alter the relative importance of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication. Understanding the role of dams in coastal eutrophication is critical for developing effective nutrient management strategies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combinations of initial conditions that led to the observed universe are biased toward states that extremize the probability of the observed state. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning problem may be more general than previously thought, and may be relevant to a wide range of dissipative systems.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the NMDA receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–induced changes in cortical microcircuitry can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of other autoimmune encephalitis.
